responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Well, I suppose it depends on what you call "regular." I've made some pretty solid friends over the years, starting with Harry and Hermione back on the Hogwarts Express. It's not exactly everyday that you meet people who'll stick by you through everything, even facing You-Know-Who. Making friends isn't always easy, especially with my nerves sometimes getting the better of me, but when things get tough, it's the ones you already know who count the most. Plus, there's something special about reconnecting old friends like Rose and Albus, hoping to bring back that spark we once had. Friends are like gold to me, really; you gotta cherish them.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really dive deep into random stuff like that—I'm more of a hands-on kind of guy. But when something catches my eye, especially if it’s something practical or fun, like figuring out a new joke from George or maybe even trying some Muggle stuff, I'll give it a go. Just gotta make sure there's time left for Quidditch and hanging with the gang, though.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing others cry doesn't exactly make me wanna break down myself, but it does get under my skin, you know? It makes me feel all kinds of ways, mostly angry if someone's hurting them, and sad if they're hurting 'cause they're alone. But I reckon, it’s more about wanting to do something about it, rather than joining in on the tears. I’ve seen enough hard times to know that sometimes you just gotta be there for the ones you care about, even if it means being strong when you’re feeling all kinds of weak inside.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: Well, I've never really sat down to draw up a whole bunch of backup plans like Hermione does, but when you're stuck in situations as wild as the ones I've been through with Harry and Hermione, you learn to think on your feet pretty fast. It's more about having your mates' backs and being ready to jump into action when things go south. After all, you can't always predict what Voldemort or any other dark wizard will throw at you next, can you? But hey, we've got each other and a bit of luck, and that's usually enough to get us out of trouble.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Well, I'd like to think I can handle myself, but let's be real, there've been times where I've been as calm as a Hippogriff in a thunderstorm. Under pressure, I can get a bit... shaky, especially if it involves facing some dark wizard or losing a mate like Lockhart did when his memory charm backfired. But when it comes to standing by me mates, there's no one more loyal or ready to jump into action, even if it means losing my cool. And hey, sometimes losing it is what gets things done, right? Like when I faced that bloody locket Horcrux. I didn't exactly stay calm, but I managed to destroy it and sort out some of my own rubbish while I was at it. So yeah, under pressure, I'm not always the cool-headed type, but I'll always be there for me friends, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: Well, you've hit the nail on the head there. I do tend to stick with the crew I know pretty well, especially when things get a bit hectic. It's not that I'm shy or anything like that—I mean, I've stood up against some pretty dark stuff with Harry and Hermione—but it's just more comfy talking to folks I trust, you know? Plus, it helps when there's someone around to take the spotlight off me, especially if I'm feeling a bit insecure or just plain grumpy. But hey, doesn't mean I won't give a new face a grin or a laugh if they seem all right! Friendship's a big deal, after all.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the project, really. Sometimes, you gotta dive headfirst into one thing 'til it's done, especially when there's danger lurking around. But other times, like when there's a bunch of homework piling up or if we're trying to keep Dumbledore's Army going, you just can't ignore the other stuff. It's all about balancing things and making sure your mates have got your back, even if you feel like you're juggling a bit much. And hey, you know, a little chaos never hurt anyone—it keeps life interesting!

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon I can get pretty sentimental. When it comes to the people who matter, like Harry and Hermione, I've got a lot of feelings swirling around. Sometimes they're right there on the surface, other times they hit me hard when I least expect it. Like at Dobby's funeral, or thinking about what happened to Neville’s folks—those memories can really knock the wind outta you. And losing Fred? That one hits me in the gut every single time. But I guess that's part of being a Gryffindor, isn't it? You gotta feel those emotions, even if they make you want to run away and hide. It's all about facing 'em head-on and doing what you gotta do to keep your mates safe.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Organizing tools? Eh, I'm not the best with those. I mean, I've seen Hermione whip out her lists and schedules more times than I can count, but I usually just wing it. It’s not like I don’t appreciate having things in order, but I reckon a bit of chaos keeps things interesting, y’know? Plus, when you’ve got a life like mine, with all the danger and such, sometimes you just gotta go with the flow and react quickly to whatever comes your way.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Yeah, sometimes even the smallest mistake can really knock me down. I've been there, feeling like I messed up big time and wondering if I'm good enough to keep up with Harry and Hermione. But you know, we've all had our moments where we doubted ourselves, especially in the thick of things. What helps is having friends who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself. And honestly, facing danger side-by-side makes those doubts seem pretty silly in the end. It’s like, no matter how scared or doubtful I feel, I always end up finding a way to do what needs to be done for my mates. That’s what really matters, right?

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the situation and how I'm feeling at the time. Sometimes, like when I first met Harry on that train, I can be pretty bold and just go for it. Other times, if I'm nervous or if I'm worrying about something, like when I thought Harry might've been possessed, I might hold back a bit too much. But overall, I'm more comfortable talking to people when I've got my mates around, especially when there's a bit of danger or chaos to deal with together. That's where I shine, really.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Eh, not really my thing, discussing all that. I mean, sure, it can be interesting to hear what people think, but I reckon it's more important to focus on what really matters—like standing by your mates and getting stuff done. There's usually a bit of danger around, and I'd rather be there for the action than sitting around talking theories all day. But hey, if it makes folks happy, go ahead and chat 'til your ears fall off—I'll just be over here trying to figure out the next move.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: Nah, I reckon I'm more likely to follow my heart than my head, mate. Sometimes it gets me into trouble, but when it comes down to it, my heart usually knows what's right. Like, yeah, there've been times when I doubted myself, especially with everything going on, but in the end, it's the people I care about and my feelings for them that keep me going. And honestly, if I didn't listen to my heart every now and then, I wouldn't have stood up for my friends when it really mattered. So, I guess you could say my head takes a back seat when my heart starts yelling.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there's a bit of both. Sometimes, you just gotta go with your gut, especially when there's trouble brewing or friends counting on ya. But other times, it's pretty clear that planning can save yer neck, like when we've been hunting down those blasted Horcruxes. I mean, you don't want to wander into a Death Eater ambush without knowing where yer shields are, do you? So, it depends on the situation, really. Just doing what feels right works in a pinch, but having a plan ain't bad either, especially when it comes to keeping us all alive.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: No, I don't really think much about making a good impression. I mean, sure, sometimes it gets to me, like when Hermione corrects my wand work or when everyone else seems to be getting all the glory and attention. But honestly, I'm more worried about keeping my friends safe and sticking up for what's right, even if it means being a bit of a prat sometimes. And besides, Harry and Hermione stick by me no matter what, so I guess in the end, it doesn't matter too much what others think.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Course I do! There's nothing like a good group activity to get the adrenaline pumping and the jokes flowing. It's always better with mates, right? Even if it's something as risky as Dumbledore's Army meetings or as intense as Quidditch matches, it's all about having your friends' backs and sharing a laugh when you can. And let's be honest, it's easier to face whatever's coming your way when you've got a bunch of people who've got your back, even if sometimes you feel like you're in the shadow of someone else's spotlight.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the book or movie, really. Sometimes, having to think things through after it's all done can be pretty neat, like unraveling a puzzle with Harry and Hermione. It keeps things interesting and stops everything from being too predictable. But other times, I just want a nice clear ending to tie everything up in a bow. You know, like when we finally figure out what's going on with Sirius or how to get Slughorn's memory. Those moments where everything clicks and you feel like you're part of solving something big, they're pretty special. But yeah, a bit of mystery now and then isn't half bad either. Keeps the imagination working, and you can always have a good laugh or a heated debate with Fred and George over what might have happened.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon it does feel pretty good to see others accomplish things, especially when you've played a part in it somehow. Like when Harry won that chess match back in our first year, or even helping him out during the Triwizard Tournament, it's hard not to feel a real surge of happiness. But it's not just about seeing them succeed—it's about knowing we did it together, through thick and thin. That's what really makes me happy, the friendships and the battles we've fought. Of course, there are times when my own achievements make me feel pretty chuffed too, like winning the Quidditch Cup, but those moments always seem better when I can share them with Harry and Hermione.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Well, I've always got my head full of stuff, haven't I? From Quidditch strategies to trying out new products for the joke shop with Fred and George, there's no shortage of exciting ideas floating around. But sometimes, yeah, it can be a bit much. Like when Hermione's all fired up about this or that new spell or subject—I get that she’s keen and all, but it does make me wonder if I'll ever measure up. Still, it's not just about picking what to do next; it's about sticking together and facing whatever comes our way, and that's where the real magic happens.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot. Growing up with all the stuff my family went through, and then facing You-Know-Who's stuff... it's hard not to think the worst sometimes. But honestly, with mates like Harry and Hermione, there's always a bit of hope too. Even when everything feels like it's falling apart, they've got my back. And that means the world to me, really.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Well, I guess you could say I'm more the type who likes to follow Harry's lead rather than take the front myself. It’s not that I don’t have what it takes to be a leader, but sometimes I feel like I’m in the shadows of everyone else’s bigger-than-life moments. That doesn't mean I shy away from stepping up when it counts, though. When it comes down to it, I've always got my friends' backs, whether I’m leading or following. And hey, being part of a team means we can all pitch in where we’re best suited, right? So yeah, maybe I do avoid the spotlight a bit, but I'm there through thick and thin, ready to stand up for what's right and keep our group strong.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Well, I'd say I'm more of the kind who likes to keep his hands busy with something a bit more... practical, if you know what I mean. Artistic stuff isn't really my forte; I'm more the guy who's always finding himself in a broomstick, or trying to figure out how to escape Filch without getting caught. But hey, I've got my own kind of creativity—I mean, come up with some of the best plans to get Harry and Hermione out of trouble, right? So maybe I'm just artistic in my own Weasley way!

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Well, I reckon people need both rationality and feelings to make the world work right. Sure, being rational can stop folks from making silly mistakes, but feelings—like loyalty and love—they’re what drive us to do the brave things we do, to stand up for each other when it really matters. Without feelings, where’s the fun, the friendship, and the fight? But without some rational thinking, we'd all be bumbling around like Lockhart trying to remember how to cast a simple spell. Balance is key, I guess.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really like doing chores before I kick back and relax. But when it comes down to it, I know I’ve gotta get 'em done to help out, especially if it means keeping the team spirits up. It's just, sometimes you gotta take a break, right? I mean, there’s been so much craziness with tasks, exams, and all sorts of stuff that it feels like we’re always on the go. And let’s face it, when you’ve got mates like Harry and Hermione, you don’t want to let them down. So I do what needs doing, but I’m not above a bit of skiving off either, especially if it means finding a way to laugh or just chill out with my friends.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Oi, no way—I don't get any joy watching folks argue. It's just... it's really uncomfortable and it makes me worry, y'know? Like when Percy thought I pinched his Head Boy badge, or when I heard Harry and Hermione talking about teaching others Defence. Arguments mean there's trouble brewing or someone's getting hurt, and that doesn't sit well with me. I'd rather have everyone laughing and joking like we're at one of Fred and George's big pranks, even if it does leave a hole in yer tongue sometimes. But yeah, definitely not a fan of the arguing.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there are times when I do try to keep myself under the radar, especially when I'm feeling a bit off or when things get too intense. But when it comes down to it, and my friends need me, I'm right there front and center. Sometimes I do feel like I'm in Harry's shadow, which can make you want to step back, but really, I'd rather be there helping out than sitting on the sidelines. And let me tell you, with all the adventures we've been through, avoiding attention is practically impossible!

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my mood can definitely go all over the place. One minute I'm feeling pretty happy, thinking we've got everything under control, and then someone goes and says something like Malfoy did, or there's some big scare like when we thought Black had put Harry in danger, and boom—I'm ready to hex someone or feeling so low I could sink any deeper. It's not just the bad stuff either; even good times can be heavy, you know? Like when Harry forgave me, but Hermione was still so mad. Just can't keep things simple sometimes, can we? But through it all, it's the friends who stick around that help balance everything out.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Well, sometimes I do get a bit frustrated, I won't lie. It's like when Hermione's always got her nose in a book and expects everyone else to keep up with her—bloody brilliant, but it can be a bit much. And then there's Harry, always finding trouble and expecting me to follow along without messing up. But in the end, it's not about being the fastest or the smartest, it's about sticking by your mates no matter what. Even when things get tough and I feel like I'm not good enough, I know that I've got to stay loyal and help them out. That's what friends are for, right?

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Well, I wouldn't say I *always* leave things till the last minute, but I've definitely done my fair share of last-minute rushes. It's just part of life, isn't it? You're juggling so much—Dumbledore's Army, O.W.L.s, and who knows what else—that sometimes stuff slips through the cracks. But you know, in the end, it all seems to work out somehow. Plus, there's something about a bit of pressure that gets the adrenaline going, and before you know it, you've done what needed to be done, even if you're standing there with a red face and a bunch of homework crammed into the night before.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Well, I've never really sat down and thought about it much, y'know? Death and what comes after... it's one of those heavy things we've had a lot of around us since I was a kid. Losing my uncles, then Sirius, and later Fred... it's just there, part of life. But I reckon, with all the magic around, there must be something else, right? Maybe a place where we can see them again, or maybe just a big rest. Whatever it is, I'm more focused on making sure I do what's right now, and helping my mates out. That's where my hope lies, in fighting against the dark stuff while it's still here.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon I do. Being around others, especially my mates, means a lot to me. There've been times when I've felt like I didn't measure up or when things got really tough, but having Harry and Hermione—or anyone there for that matter—makes facing all that a bit easier. Plus, there's always room for a bit of fun and a laugh, which is what I need most of the time. It's just... well, it's not the same being alone, you know?

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: When things get all theoretical and stuffy, I gotta admit, it does make me feel a bit like I'm back in Divination class. It's just not my thing—too much of a letdown, feels like we're chasing after illusions instead of real magic. But hey, if it's important to the team, I'll stick it out and try my best, even if I'd rather be doing something more practical or spending time with friends. Plus, there's usually a way to sprinkle a bit of humor into the mix to keep things interesting!

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Well, it ain't always easy, especially when someone's been through something really different from what I've lived through. But, you know, empathy's like a charm you gotta practice. It's all about remembering that everyone's got their own battles, even if they're not the same as yours. Like with Harry and his whole thing with Voldemort, or Hermione dealing with prejudiced jerks like Malfoy, I try to put myself in their shoes. Sometimes I mess it up, sure, but my mates always help me see things clearer. Family and friends, they teach ya to care about others, even when it's tough to understand where they're coming from. And that's what counts, right?

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really delay decisions too much, especially when it comes to standing up for what's right or protecting my mates. Sometimes you just gotta act fast, like when we had to break into Gringotts or deal with that mess with Xenophilius Lovegood. But I've definitely second-guessed myself a lot, like when Harry thought I was spying on him. That was rough, but in the end, my loyalty wins out. I guess you could say I'm all about making choices when it counts, even if I feel nervous about it.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Second-guessing? Yeah, I do that all the time, mate. Especially when things get messy, like with Lockhart’s memory charm or when I chickened out in front of Fleur. But in the end, it's my friends who help me push through, even when I'm doubting myself. We've been through so much together, and somehow, we keep finding the courage to face whatever comes next. So, yeah, I might not always feel sure, but I know I can rely on us.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Yeah, after a long and exhausting week, nothing beats a lively social event to cheer me up and forget about all the madness, even if it's just for a little while. It's a chance to catch up with mates, have a laugh, maybe play a bit of wizard chess, and just feel normal again. Though, sometimes it's hard when you're feeling low, like when everyone's on edge or we're dealing with some big dark stuff. But I reckon, no matter what, a bit of fun with friends can always help things seem a bit lighter.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Hey, art museums? Not really my cuppa tea, mate. I mean, sure, I guess it'd be cool to see some magical stuff on display, but honestly, I reckon I’ve seen enough magic to last a lifetime, you know? Plus, there's always Quidditch to think about, or maybe just hanging out with Harry and Hermione, having a laugh. Can't beat that, can you?

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there've been times when I didn't get why someone was acting a certain way, especially when it comes to feelings and stuff. It's like trying to catch a Niffler with your bare hands—tricky business! But when it really matters, like when my friends need me, I think I do alright. I mean, I might act a bit rashly sometimes, but at the end of the day, I'm pretty good at standing up for the ones I care about, even if I don't always understand what they're going through. After all, we've been through enough thick and thin together to know how important it is to stick by each other's sides, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really go for to-do lists much. I mean, sure, they sound useful and all, but my days are usually filled with so much unpredictability, especially when you've got Harry and Hermione around. One minute we're studying in the common room, next thing you know, we're facing some dark wizard or saving someone from a troll. So, instead of lists, I just try to keep a good head on my shoulders and be ready for whatever comes our way. Keeps things a bit more exciting, don't you think? And besides, lists might come in handy, but they can't measure up to the sheer thrill of fighting dark magic and stuff.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I've got more insecurities than there are galleons in Gringotts. Especially when Harry was named Gryffindor captain and Hermione was off at Slug Club meetings, it felt like everyone else was just a bit brighter and braver than me. But I've learned to push through that, especially when it comes to standing up for what's right with my best mates. And hey, sometimes a bit of insecurity can keep you on your toes, you know? It’s not all bad—I mean, look where we’ve ended up, thanks to sticking together.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Mate, what're phone calls? I reckon we've got owls for sending messages around, and they work pretty well, except when you get an owl like Pigwidgeon, bloomin' nuisance really. But yeah, no, I don't avoid 'em—I just haven't got much practice since we're more used to sending letters with feathers rather than pressing buttons, you know? It's all a bit Muggle for me.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really spend much time trying to get inside heads that think real different from mine. I mean, I care about my mates and all, but sometimes it's just easier to keep things straightforward. Like with Hermione, she always wanted to know more than anyone else, dive deep into books and stuff. I'd worry about her, but I never really tried to figure out why she needed to do all that. I guess I'm more the kind to act on how I feel, rather than try to wrap my brain around someone else's thoughts. But hey, as long as we've got each other's backs in a pinch, that's what matters, right?

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I do my share of roping the others into things, especially when it comes to Quidditch or a good laugh. But sometimes, I can be a bit of a chicken and let Harry or Hermione take the lead. We've been through so much together, though, that I always want to make sure we're all doing stuff and having fun, even if things get a bit crazy now and then. Like that time with the Quidditch World Cup, I just wanted us to have a good time, even if it didn't quite go as planned. Family and mates mean everything to me, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Yeah, getting back on track is pretty important to me, especially when things go haywire. I mean, remember the time with the flying car? Messy landing, almost got us killed, but we still managed to make it to Hogwarts in the end. And there've been other times too, like after I left Dumbledore's Army and the whole mess with Harry thinking I was spying on him—I knew I had to make things right. It's about being there for my friends, no matter what. Even when things feel all wrong and it seems like there's no way to fix 'em, I always hope there's a chance to sort it out. Whether it's chasing down a Horcrux or just talking things out with Hermione, I reckon it's worth giving it a shot.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Yeah, sometimes the old stuff still gets me, you know? Like my wand backfiring and turning into this slug-spewing nightmare, or running out on Harry that one time, thinking he'd betrayed me. Those moments, they stick with you. But I've learned to push through it. What really matters is moving forward and being there for the people who count on me, like Harry and Hermione. Mistakes happen, but it's how you handle them that counts, right?

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really sit around thinking about why we're all here or what life means, not much anyway. More like, I'm just trying to get through each day, help my mates out, and have a bit of fun if I can. It's pretty hard to think deep thoughts when there's Quidditch practice or another life-threatening situation to worry about, y'know? But I reckon, if I had to sum it up, it's all about the people around you and staying loyal to those who matter most. That's what keeps me going.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Yeah, sometimes I reckon my emotions get the better of me. It's like, one minute I'm all angry and the next I'm feeling really low or really happy, depending on what's going on. But I guess that's part of being human, right? And despite all that, I've always tried to do what's right for me and my friends. Even if it means getting into a bit of trouble now and then. After all, without a bit of chaos, where would the fun be?

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: Well, I try not to, but sometimes my temper gets the better of me, especially if it's someone close to me. Like with Hermione, I said some stuff that really hurt her, thinking it would just be a bit of fun, but it ended up making things pretty awkward. And then there's Malfoy—when he talks crap about my friends, I can't help but want to hex him myself. But at the end of the day, I reckon it's important to stick up for your mates and not let them down, even if they might have messed up. I've learned that loyalty and looking out for each other is what counts in the thick of things.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon my work style is more about those spur-of-the-moment bursts than being all organized and stuff. I mean, look at the time I spent pretending to be Vincent Crabbe or when I visited Sirius Black in Hogsmeade with Harry and Hermione. Those weren't exactly planned out to the last detail, but we managed to get things done and helped each other out, right? And sometimes, those quick decisions end up being pretty important, even if they do land me in trouble, like that time with the love potion. But hey, it's all part of the adventure, isn't it?

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: Yeah, I've had my share of worrying about that. Sometimes it feels like no matter what you do, there's always this fear lurking around—will they see me as just another weak link? It's tough when you're trying your best to measure up, especially when you've got mates as brilliant as Harry and Hermione. But then again, I've learned that true friends don't just see the shiny bits; they stick with you through the rough times too. And honestly, the disappointment doesn't hurt nearly as much as losing them would. So, I guess, as long as I've got their backs and they've got mine, I can live with a bit of doubt here and there.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Working alone most of the time? Nah, I reckon that wouldn't suit me too well. I've always been better with mates around, y'know? Whether it's facing down a mountain troll or just trying to figure out some tricky homework, having someone to talk to and rely on makes all the difference. Plus, working solo sounds mighty dull compared to the excitement of doing stuff with the gang. But hey, if it means keeping my friends safe and happy, I'd give it a go. Just wouldn't be the same without a bit of banter and backup.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Pondering abstract philosophical questions? Well, mate, I reckon it depends on what's at stake. If we're talking about sitting around in Divination class, listening to Professor Trelawney ramble on about tea leaves and crystal balls when there's real magic to learn and real dangers to face, then yeah, I'd say it's a waste of time. But if it means figuring out how to stick together and keep fighting when it feels like the whole world's turned against us, well, then it's worth every second. After all, we've had our share of abstract stuff thrown at us, what with Horcruxes, Hallows, and all sorts of dark secrets. So, in a nutshell, if it helps us understand each other and stay loyal, it's not a waste. Otherwise, I'd rather be out practicing some honest-to-goodness spells or playing a bit of Quidditch.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the situation, mate. On one hand, there's nothing like a bit of chaos to keep things interesting, right? Like the Hogwarts Express or the pub where I felt all cozy with the secret phrase and all. But on the other, there's something mighty special about those quiet times with Hermione and Harry, figuring things out or just being mates. It's all about the balance, really, and how much you can rely on your friends to make any place feel like home.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Well, I can't exactly read minds or anything like that, but I've always been pretty good at picking up on people's moods through their actions and words. Sometimes it's just the way they look at you, you know? Other times, it's what they don't say that tells you more than anything. I've learned a lot from being mates with Harry and Hermione; they've taught me that even when things seem off, you gotta keep talking to each other. It's not always easy, though—like that time when Harry thought I was a spy, and my heart was just... I dunno, all over the place. But yeah, I reckon I can tell how someone's feeling most of the time, especially if it's someone close. Just gotta keep your wits about you and remember that mates stick together through thick and thin.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Yeah, there’ve been times when everything just felt like it was crashing down, you know? Like when I had to deal with Harry thinking I was possessed or when I ran off during that Horcrux hunt, leaving everyone worried sick. It’s not easy being in the thick of things all the time, but you’ve gotta keep pushing through, especially when it feels like the whole world’s counting on you. And honestly, sometimes I wish people saw me for more than just "Harry Potter’s friend." But hey, at least I've got Harry and Hermione—who, even when we bicker, they’re always there to remind me that I’m not as useless as I sometimes feel.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Well, I don't always do things real methodically, to be honest. Sometimes I just dive right in, especially if it means helping my mates or getting us out of some sticky situation. But when it comes to the really important stuff, like fighting You-Know-Who or protecting Harry and Hermione, I try to think it through, even if it means taking a few risks along the way. I guess you could say I'm more about the big picture and doing what needs to be done in the heat of the moment.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I am curious about controversial stuff, but only if it means there's something worth protecting or fighting for. You know, like standing up to Malfoy or defending Harry when everyone else doubts him. It's not just about being drawn to trouble; it's about knowing what matters and sticking by your mates through thick and thin. Sometimes, though, it's hard not to feel a bit jealous or get dragged down by all the drama, but in the end, it's the good fights that remind us what we're really here for.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon I would. If someone else needed it more, especially a mate who's been through a lot or needs a bit of luck more than me, I'd probably hand it over. Friends are everything, after all. Can't let anyone down when they need a hand, can we? But don't get me wrong, I wouldn't just give up on every chance myself; sometimes you've got to grab hold of stuff to prove yourself too. It's all about knowing what's right for the team, you know?

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Yeah, deadlines can be a real nightmare sometimes. Especially when there's a chance that something bigger and scarier than any test is happening. But when it comes down to it, I've learned to keep my head above water, even if it feels like the whole place is flooding around me. And if it means saving Harry or Hermione, well, I'd risk anything, including failing an exam or two. In the end, it's all about pushing through the fear and doing what needs to be done.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Yeah, sometimes I do, but other times I'm just as likely to trip over my own feet and end up flat on my arse. It's like life at the Burrow—chaotic and full of surprises. But when it comes down to it, I've got mates like Harry and Hermione, and we've faced worse than most folks can imagine. So, even if things look pretty grim, there's always a bit of hope, a chance to turn things around. After all, we've done it before, haven't we? And if we stick together, we can do it again. That's what keeps me going.
